FacilityName: Gallade Chemical, Inc. - Santa Ana (Fed Filing)

_prev_prog_2.CH_OtherChanges: Repacking and refilling operation activities from 55-gallon drums to 1-gallon containers have ceased onsite for 70% Hydrofluoric Acid.

_emerg_resp.LEPCCoordinationReason: LEPC delegates coordination with the local fire department (OC Fire Authority)

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This document comprises the Federal RMP for the Gallade Chemical facility located in Santa Ana, California (hereinafter referred to as the site or the subject site).  The site is owned and operated by Gallade Chemical, Inc.

The purpose of this document is to comply with the risk management planning and update requirements as outlined in the Code of Federal, Title 40 Part 68 (also known as the Federal RMP Regulations).  The scope of the RMP includes all operations conducted at the subject site that involve the storage and handling of regulated substances.  The only regulated substance stored and handled at the facility that meets the Federal RMP applicability is:

	Hydrofluoric acid (70-percent concentration)

1.  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Gallade Chemical has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the covered process. Gallade's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances.

2.  DESCRIPTIONS OF STATIONARY SOURCES AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED
The primary operation conducted by Gallade Chemical, Inc. at the Santa Ana Facility is Chemical Distribution (NAICS Code 42489 - Other Chemical and Allied Products Merchant Wholesalers). The Gallade Chemical Facility is located at 1230 East St. Gertrude Place in Santa Ana, California 92707. The Facility is located in an area that is primarily industrial and bounded by East St. Gertrude Place to the north and industrial facilities to the east, south, and west. Gallade Chemical's Santa Ana Facility is a chemical distribution facility and started its operation in 1973 to distribute industrial chemicals to retail operators and wholesale distributors. As part of normal operations, the Facility purchases, receives, and stores onsite in p

re-packaged and sealed drums of 70-Percent Concentrated Hydrofluoric Acid. Hydrofluoric Acid (70-percent concentrated) is received at the Facility in 55-Gallon drums and stored onsite in an enclosed building until it can be delivered to the various customer sites.  

3.  GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
The Accidental Release Prevention Program at the facility consists of a series of programs, procedures, and policies designed to minimize the risk of accidental releases involving regulated substances.  These programs include design and operating controls such as compliance with specified codes (i.e. compliance with building codes and fire codes, conformance to the Chemical Manufacturer's Association Responsible Care Program, Corporate policies for segregation of classes of hazardous substances such as strong acids, strong bases, weak acids, weak bases, etc.), the Company's OSHA Hazard Communication Program, numerous standard operating procedures, the equipment inspection, and maintenance program (including mechanical integrity and preventive maintenance program for forklifts, etc.), fire protection, accident/incident investigation procedures, emergency response plan, the RMP Program compliance auditing program, and a variety of personnel training programs.  

4.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
During the five years preceding the submittal of this RMP 5-year update, the subject site has NOT had any releases of regulated substances (i.e., 70-percent concentrated hydrofluoric acid) that have resulted in:

      1. Onsite deaths, injuries, or 
      2. Significant property damage; or
      3. Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

5.  EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
Gallade Chemical recognizes that emergency planning and emergency response are an integral component of risk management. As such, the Company, as part of its hazardous materials busin

ess plan (HMBP) for the Santa Ana Facility, has developed and implemented an emergency action/response plan and an emergency evacuation plan.  
 

6.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
The planned changes to improve safety at the facility include resolving the identified issues and implementing recommendations derived from the technical evaluation and analysis such as hazard review/process hazard analysis, seismic assessment analysis, compliance audits and incident investigations as applicable. The facility has a tracking system for implementing these recommendations and ensuring its closure. As required by the regulations, recommendations are addressed and closed on time before the regulatory or voluntary due date as applicable.
